references: As illustrated in Fig. 1, we consider a system model that comprises a cloud server, a set of edge servers, which form mobile edge networks, denoted as ğ’¦={k:k=1,â€¦.,K}\mathcal{K}=\{k:k=1,....,K\}, K=|ğ’¦|ğ¾ğ’¦K=|\mathcal{K}|, and set of clients ğ’©={n:n=1,â€¦,N}ğ’©conditional-setğ‘›ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘\mathcal{N}=\{n:n=1,...,N\}, N=|ğ’©|ğ‘ğ’©N=|\mathcal{N}|. It is worth mentioning that in the context of vehicular networks and intelligent transportation systems, edge servers are commonly referred to as Roadside Units (RSUs). Each client owns its local dataset, ğ’Ÿnsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›\mathcal{D}_{n}, to train model parameters locally and then send them to its edge server in the mobile edge network. The number of data samples in each ğ’Ÿnsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›\mathcal{D}_{n} is Dn=|ğ’Ÿn|subscriptğ·ğ‘›subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›D_{n}=|\mathcal{D}_{n}|, with ğ’Ÿnsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›\mathcal{D}_{n} representing the following input-output pairing: ({xi,d(n)âˆˆâ„d,yi(n)}i=1Dn)superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘–1subscriptğ·ğ‘›(\{{x}^{(n)}_{i,d}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},~{}y^{(n)}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{D_{n}}), where xi,d(n)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘‘{x}^{(n)}_{i,d} is the dğ‘‘d-dimensional input data vector at the nğ‘›n-th client and yi(n)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘–y^{(n)}_{i} is the corresponding label associated with xi,d(n)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘‘{x}^{(n)}_{i,d}. Each kğ‘˜k-th edge server holds a subset of clients (i.e., ğ’©kâŠ†ğ’©subscriptğ’©ğ‘˜ğ’©\mathcal{N}_{k}\subseteq\mathcal{N}), in which the edge servers are physically located in close proximity to ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N} clients to coordinate the training process. Afterward, each kğ‘˜k-th edge server aggregates the model parameters and averages them to update its edge model. In return, the cloud collects and averages the edge models from all edge servers to update a global model. During every HFL round, both the cloud and edge servers impose a deadline constraint to synchronize the updates, mitigating potential delays. For ease of presentation, Table I summarizes the key symbols used throughout this paper.

references:
This section presents the conducted simulations to evaluate the proposed approach compared to the baselines in terms of learning performance and resource consumption.
Experimental Parameters: We use a systemâ€™s bandwidth of 10 MHz, with 1 MHz for each sub-channel. The channel gain (ğ¡nrsubscriptsuperscriptğ¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘›\mathbf{h}^{r}_{n}) for each client is modeled with a path loss (Î±=gâˆ˜â€‹(dâˆ˜d)4ğ›¼subscriptğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘‘4\alpha=g_{\circ}(\frac{d_{\circ}}{d})^{4}), where gâˆ˜=âˆ’35subscriptğ‘”35g_{\circ}=-35 dB and the distance (dâˆ˜=2subscriptğ‘‘2d_{\circ}=2 m). Also, AWGN power is set to (Nâˆ˜=10âˆ’8subscriptğ‘superscript108N_{\circ}=10^{-8} watts). The client is 202020Â m to 100100100Â m away from a given edge server. The computation frequency fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} ranges between 111 GHz and 999 GHz, and the number of cycles per sample is identical for all clients, i.e., Bn=20subscriptğµğ‘›20B_{n}=20 cycle/sample. The transmit power Pnrsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ‘›P^{r}_{n} varies between the upper bound pnmâ€‹aâ€‹x=20subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘›20p^{max}_{n}=20 dBm and lower bound pnmâ€‹iâ€‹n=âˆ’10subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘›10p^{min}_{n}=-10 dBm.
Dataset Preprocessing:
To measure the effectiveness of our proposed approach, we carry out a series of simulations using the FEMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasetsÂ [44, 45]. These datasets are widely used for handwriting classification and object recognition tasks, respectively, in the FL setting. Specifically, the CIFAR-10 dataset can be used in autonomous vehicles, where image recognition and interpretation are crucial for safe and efficient operation. FEMNIST explicitly helps classify letters and digits (A-Z, a-z, and 0-9), comprising 244,154 images for training and 61,500 for testing, while CIFAR-10 comprises 60,000 32x32 colored images. Also, we apply these datasets in a non-IID fashion, partitioning them into ğ’¥ğ’¥\mathcal{J} fragments and restricting each client to hold only two random classes. Regarding the model architecture, a convolutional neural network (CNN) classifier is employed for FEMNIST, which is integrated with two hidden layers, while Alexnet, a deep neural network (DNN), is utilized for CIFAR-10. The Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU) activation function is applied to the hidden layers in both learning tasks, while the output layer utilizes the Softmax activation function. For local training, we partition 80%percent8080\% for training and 20%percent2020\% for testing. The simulation parameters are listed in TableÂ II for ease of presentation.
